titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: I find myself already falling into idleness as always happens after I have completed a compulsive task, and am left without another bearing upon me— The luxury of my life is desultory reading, and my library furnishes irresistible temptation to variety of enjoyment— My first duty now is to answer Letters of invitation to deliver Orations, Lectures and Addresses, and I began with that of B. R. Curtis for an Address to the Alumni of Harvard University on the day before the next Commencement— The next was from R. F. Barnard President of the Berkshire County Agricultural Society, inviting me to deliver an Address to that Society at their annual meeting next October—to both these I wrote and despatched declining answers—but in addition to the Berkshire invitation there is a Letter from Charles Sedgwick and 49 others dated at Lenox, and another from Thaddeus Pomeroy and 22 others at Stockbridge which I ought to have answered this day but postponed till to-morrow— A man by the name of Matthias Rich, blind, came, led by his Son, a boy about 12 years of age came to beg. He had an old certificate of respectability and of indigence dated in 1839. and signed by John Reed the former member of Congress from Barnstable County— He said that he had a family of several children to support, and no other means but the bounty of the charitable to assist him; which from time to time he went round to solicit, though it was a very mortifying occupation— Mr Tyler too came again this afternoon and resumed his volunteer task of varnishing all over the house every thing upon which he could lay his hand— I rode out this afternoon with Mrs Charles and her Son Charles— We stop’d at Mrs T. B. Adams’s and left a Letter from Mrs De Windt to her in reply to condolence on the decease of Mr Whittemore— The Letter announces also the birth of a Son to Mrs Van Wagenen, who was Julia the third daughter of Mrs De Windt— We then round by the Railway Stone Church. After our return, Mr Thomas J. Noyes with his brother came to enquire what had been done in Congress on the petition of their Grandmother Mary Pike for a pension; of which I had taken charge, 14. Novr last— Her husband was killed at Bunker’s hill— I told them that a Bill in her favour had passed the house of Representatives, but I believe had failed in the Senate—but not having with me the Acts of the last Session of Congress I was unable to answer the enquiry with certainty— I attended this Evening at the town hall an anatomical lecture by a young man named Lambert—chiefly against the compression of the chest, by straight-lacing—from 8 to 1/2 past 9—
Sun rose 4.25. clear and pinching cold.

I saw the sun rise from the S.E. corner of Charles’s house. I answered the Letters of Charles Sedgwick and Thaddeus Pomeroy, but continued idle with miscellaneous reading, and believing that I must prepare a Lecture for the next Autumn, meditated upon a biographical sketch of Lord Bacon of Nicholas Machiavel, of Ignatius Loyola and Blaise Pascal, either of which seems to afford a good subject for a moral and entertaining Lecture— But if this is ever to be carried into execution it must be preceded by much reading. I took up the life of Bacon in the first Volume of the Quarto Edition of his works, and read about an hour. I met Mr E. Price Greenleaf in my garden, and walked round with him examining my seedling trees.— I mourned the number of various kinds and ages apparently killed by the recent frosts after putting forth their foliage with cheering promise— Of the Baldwin Apple trees from Medford, two at least have holes of the borer worm two or three inches above the ground— Several of them bore largely last autumn, and we have now as many as a peck of them in sound condition, daily on the dining table. Of the Shagbark walnut there arein the Nurseryin the Garden andin the seminary which I have hope will outlive me more than a century— The peaches and button woods have a dreary and haggard appearance—many of them entirely dead.— Mr Greenleaf brought back a number of books that he had borrowed and asked for others—among which Montesquieu and Machiavel in French and Italian— This last I have not. but I found in the town’s library an English translation of Machiavel’s works, not including the plays; in 4. 8vo. volumes by Ellis Farneworth published in 1775— I looked especially for the Prince and found it with a translation of the Anti-Machiavel, by Frederic 2. king of Prussia, printed alternately chapter by chapter— Several of which I read—first the cunning Italian, and then the royal German-French commentator. Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine— He brought information of the arrival of our chests and trunks and boxes, ship’d at Georgetown in the brig Elizabeth Captain Baker, but fraudulently landed at Salem— He brought me also a Letter from Mr Savage, President of the Massachusetts Historical Society, with a vote of thanks of the Society for the Discourse on the New England Confederacy, and a request of a copy for the press. Mr Tyler was here varnishing— Ruth Turner to work— Elizabeth C. Adams to dine—and we rode to Milton after dinner.

Mr Tyler continues to favour us with volunteer varnishing—and this day wrought almost a metempsecosis on the full length portrait of my great grandfather John Quincy, at two years of age, painted in 1691. and left by his Son Norton Quincy, who died 29. September 1801— He brought me also a Boston Notion of this morning, containing a report of the celebration of last Monday; with seven columns of my discourse from the Notes of the Reporter— There are many mistakes, of the meaning; but I believe it scarcely possible that a more correct report of a speech nearly two hours long, should be taken from the lips of the Speaker.— I despatched 3 Letters of apology, for declining to deliver the address before the Berkshire County Agricultural Society next October— Mr E. Price Greenleaf came and returned more of the books that he had borrowed; and took from the Town’s library the 6. volumes of the works of Montesquieu in duodecimo and 2. volumes of Italian History. I read several chapters of Machiavel’s Prince, and the examen of the same by Frederic of Prussia.— I believe that a profound examination of both would form an instructive and entertaining occupation for this and the next Month—why should I not undertake it?— Machiavel, was a republican, Florentine Statesman of the 15th. Century— Frederic the 2d. a German Prussian King of the 18th. and Voltaire a French Man of Letters and universal Genius of the same age— Frederic wrote his Anti-Machiavel, while he was a Prince, and before he became a king.— He wrote in the French language, and the first edition of his work was published by Voltaire in Holland. The morality of Machiavel characterizes his Age and country; and is congenial to the doctrines of papal Rome at the time when Luther first raised the standard of religious reformation.— Machiavel was born 1469. and Luther 1483. and Ignatius Loyola 1491.— Comparing the Chapters of the Prince with the Examen of Frederic, the Royal commentator has greatly the advantage—but Voltaire in the posthumous Memoirs of his own life, charges Frederic with practising on the doctrines of Machiavel, however indignantly denouncing them in his youthful writings— The infidel spirit of the 18th. century is apparent in the treatise of Frederic, though more gauze covered in the second edition published by himself, than in the first published by Voltaire.— The cold weather continues, but while we were at dinner there was a heavy shower of rain, accompanied with distant thunder— It deprived us of the afternoon, and kept me at work, writing— At evening twilight however I walked up the hill, but the roads were so muddy that I was obligated to abridge my walk and come in— I shingled this day my seedling English Oaks to save them from the Sun.

Mr Lunt preached this morning, from 1. Corinthians 10.16. “The cup of blessing which we bless, is it not the communion of the blood of Christ? The bread which we break, is it not the communion of the body of Christ?” It was a communion day Sermon, and after preaching it he administered the communion, of which I partook— There is a peculiar solemnity in this religious rite, which in the most impressive manner admonishes every sincere Christian of his duties to God, and to his neighbour; and especially of the duty of goodwill to all mankind— There is something strange and mysterious in the history of the institution of the Jewish Passover—and of the substitution of this sacrament in its stead— On the night of the going forth of the children of Israel from Egypt, the destroying angel had smitten all the first born of the Egyptians— There was not a house but had a dead body in it: but the angel had passed over all the houses of the Israelites, and in commemoration of that double deliverance, on the very night of the Exodus, Moses commanded that their religious year should commence with that month, and that every family should annually sacrifice a lamb, and feed upon it in remembrance of that wonderful event. Subsequent regulations of divine appointment had prescribed that this annual festival should be held at Jerusalem, and 1500 years after the establishment of the passover Jesus went up to that city to keep the passover with his disciples— There it was, while at supper that he disclosed the secret of his own destiny, and considering himself as the paschal lamb, sacrificed for the sins and deliverance of mankind—he told his disciples by a figure of oriental imagery that the bread was his flesh, and the wine his blood, which they must annually eat and drink in remembrance of him— And now after 3300 years, the Jewish Passover is yet annually celebrated in the form of an annual memorial of the ignominious death and glorious resurrection of Jesus of Nazareth— And once in every one or two months it is repeated by Christians even of the purest and most spiritual denomination. Mr Lunt announced and prayed for one new communicant, Samuel White— After dinner he preached again from John 3.8. “The wind bloweth where it listeth, and thou hearest the sound thereof, but canst not tell whence it cometh, and whither it goeth: so is every one who is born of the Spirit”— The spiritual nature of Christianity is a topic to which Mr Lunt very frequently returns— After Meeting I rode with Mrs Charles and her child Arthur to Germantown, and was reminded by the name of Palmer Street of the old General, once settled there.

The wind came round yesterday to the South and this morning when I rose before the Sun; thin clouds were scudding across the sky from South to North, followed by a dense fog, which soon cleared off, for a forenoon of high Summer heat— I took the opportunity to visit my seedling trees in the garden, nursery and seminary.— The exercise and the thermometer soon urged me back into the house. Of the multitude of English Oak acorns sown last October five or six have sprung up, the last week in May.— None since—and there as many more slender stalks, three or four inches high which came up last summer, and have survived the winter, and opened their leaves, but shew no manifestation of growth, the present Season— To keep these alive through another winter is my present ambition; but the black jack Oak is again winter killed nearly down to the surface of the ground— It is putting forth new shoots, but doubtful whether they will get headway to survive the next winter— The most extraordinary growth of the present year is that of my shagbark walnuts— Then the cherries, and the black walnuts; which seldom thrive here.— I had scarcely returned to my chamber when the wind shifted to the eastward and the afternoon and evening were cold and rainy— I answered a Letter from my wife, and before closing it received another from her, dated the first of this month, which will require further answer. I received also a Letter from William Hayden joint editor of the Boston Atlas, offering to publish in that paper, my Discourse on the New England confederacy; which I declined, having promised a copy for publication to the Society— I had also received last week a Letter from George Sullivan at New-York enquiring if I would deliver an Address before the American Institute of New-York, next November— I answered this day and declined. I resume the notice of the Collections of the Massachusetts Historical Society— Third Series Vol. 1— Hutchinson papers, continued from the last Volume p. 1–152 Seven Letters of Roger Williams p. 159–178— Two Letters of Hugh Peters p. 179–180. Letters of William Hooke p. 181. and of John Maidston p. 185–198 to Governor John Winthrop of Connecticut— History of the Nanhiganset Country p. 209–228— Letter of John Haynes to John Winthrop p. 229.— 3 Letters of Henry Jacie to John Winthrop junr p. 235–245. Vol. 2. Memoir of French Protestants settled at Oxford 1686. p 1.–83. New England’s Salamander discovered by Edward Winslow p. 110–146. Cotton’s vocabulary of the Massachusetts or Natick Indian Language. p 147. Memoir of the Narragansett township. p 273.— Long Parliament p 323—

There was in the Night very heavy rain, with thunder and lightening which I neither saw nor heard—though I did hear the clock strike 3— I went to Boston this morning—with my Son, his wife and daughter Louisa Catherine.— On alighting at Dr Frothingham’s house I met my old friend Mr John Welles, who greeted me very kindly— He has just returned from an excursion Southward as far as Richmond in Virginia. On his way home he has been at pains to ascertain the cause of the universal blight which for the last two years has fallen upon the button wood or Sycamore trees— They were among the largest, soundest, most flourishing and longest lived trees of our forests; and the most easily propagated, for they grew from a twig or stake as well as from the seed— Last summer they foliated very scantily, and not till near midsummer— This Season they are but now beginning to put forth rare and stinted leaves; and look like one of Hayley’s old maid’s a blasted tree in the middle of a heath—or they sadden the rich foliage of a surrounding grove, like a spot of desolation in a circle of beauty. Mr Welles thinks he has discovered the source of all this mischief, in an insect scarcely larger than a musquito— I went into Dr Frothingham’s study, and had with him a literary conversation of about two hours— I spoke of my speculations upon the morality of the 15th. century—and the Jesuits—and he referred me to an Article in the 152 number of the Edinburgh Review July 1842—on the spiritual exercises of Ignatius Loyola: and Mr Edward Brooks afterwards lent me the republication of the number containing that Article— From Dr Frothingham’s I went and spent an hour with Dr George Parkman and his wife and daughter, and the revd. Mr Mason of New-York, who came as a delegate from the New-York Historical Society to the celebration of the New-England confederacy— I met in the Street Mr Buckingham, Editor of the Courier, and President of the Bunker hill Monument Association, who told me that the Directors hoped I should attend at the ceremony of the 17th. which is to be immortalized by an Address from Daniel Webster, and the presence of President John Tyler— I answered doubtingly. Doctor Parkman returned with me to Dr Frothingham’s door. We dined at Mr Edward Brooks’s, his father being the only other guest— At 1/2 past 4. Charles left us to go, by the Railway Cars to Worcester—to attend the great whig convention to be held there to morrow, to nominate whig candidates for the Offices of Governor and Lieutenant Governor of the Commonwealth for the year 1844— I purchased a crockery ware pint pitcher, and a Turkish sponge. At 5. P.M. Mrs Charles and her daughter returned with me to Quincy—and I made up a fire again in my Study. And I wrote there two hours at the close of the Evening. Mr Minott Thayer delegate from Braintree to the Worcester Convention had called here on his way.

I succeeded in reaching the corner of my Son’s house to see the first beam of the rising Sun— Mr John A. Green. Editor of the Quincy Patriot, brought me a small volume elegantly bound with my name on the outside binding published by Casserly and Sons 108 Nassau Street New-York: with a flattering, complimentary note from the publishers— The book is entitled A Memoir of Ireland Native and Saxon, by Daniel O’Connell M.P. Vol. 1. 1172–1660— These are Roman Catholic publishers; but I know not how to account for their extraordinary kindness to me— Mr Green had also a slip from a Berkshire Newspaper containing 4 Stanzas of poetry with my name as the author. He asked if they were mine— They were the Stanza’s 3–6. of Dermot MacMorrogh—Canto 2. Green intimated that he intended to republish them in the Quincy Patriot— I visited my seedling trees, and noted the first appearance of one more English Oak— I trimmed a young button-wood and took off a stake which I planted to ascertain if it will grow.— I answered at last a Letter, which has been waiting for an answer for 12 days. After dinner I rode with Mrs Charles and her boy Arthur to Mount Wollaston, and after we returned I had a visit from John G. Whittier. He had agreed to serve as Editor of the Emancipator during the absence of Mr Leavitt; but that engagement is cancelled and at the close of this week he returns to his residence at Amesbury— He spoke of the teeming projects of our Southern politicians for the annexation of Texas to this Union; and for the counter projects in Texas for the abolition of Slavery there— I told him my reasons for distrusting the sincerity of the British Government with regard to Slavery and Texas; the commercial interest and policy of Great-Britain, sympathising far more with our Southern than with the Northern States— Past Midshipman John Quincy Adams 2d. came in this Evening with his Sister Elizabeth— He has a short furlough and from the Razee Independence of the home Squadron, has been transferred to the command of the Sloop of War Decatur—ordered to the Station, on the Coast of Africa— Collections of the Massachusetts historical Society Third Series. Vol. 3. Pathway to erect a plantation by Captain John Smith p 1–53. Plain dealing. by Thomas Lechford. p. 59.–128. Instructions to John Winthrop—Governor of Connecticut. Lion Gardener’s Relation of the Pequot War. p. 131–160. Relation of the Indian plot, p 161–164. Intrusion of Rhode-Island people on Indian Lands— p. 209. John Josselyn, two Voyages to New-England p 211–354. Chronological observations of America p 355–396.

I saw the Sun rise again from the S.E. corner of my Son’s house, but it went soon into a cloud which thickened the whole day and sprinkled rain in the evening. Mr Forbes of Milton called on me this forenoon and introduced to me a Mr Delano recently returned from China— He speaks doubtfully of the results of the late War of Great Britain against China. My Son returned before dinner from the whig convention at Worcester, where yesterday they first nominated John Davis as the whig candidate for Governor— Mr Davis positively and peremptorily declined the nomination; whereupon they nominated George N. Briggs for Governor and John Read of Yarmouth for Lieutenant Governor— There was a suspension of hostilities between the Clay and Webster fragments of the whig party, which are already bitterly exasperated against each other— Webster has undertaken to dragoon the whigs of this State from their allegiance to Henry Clay, whom he proposes to supplant, as a supplementary candidate for the Presidency; by a double coalition with John Tyler and John C. Calhoun— His first movements in this new system of policy, have demolished the prospects of Clay, and driven John Davis into retirement, but have gone near to demolish also Webster’s own party— The result thus far has been to throw the State into the hands of Marcus Morton and the radical democracy— This is but a step to that flagitious coalition which is to prostrate the freedom of this Union before its Slavery. What am I to do in this struggle? to flinch ingloriously from it? or to perish in fruitless resistance ag against it? Is it not a craven Spirit, that holds me still in suspense on this mighty movement upon the history of man. Miss Welsh came out with Charles from Boston— I took a ride with her and Mrs Charles and her this afternoon— We left her at Mrs Torrey’s and after a tour round the old roads in Braintree, took her up again at Mrs T. B. Adams’s— I had in the morning a visit from Mr Joseph Graves of Brentwood in the County of Rockingham, New Hampshire— He said he was travelling this way, and called to see me, from mere curiosity— Collections of the Massachusetts historical Society Third Series Vol. 5. Journal of the proceedings of the Congress held at Albany 1754. p. 5–14. Journal of the Treaty held at Albany in August 1775 with the six Nations, by the Commissioners of the 12. United Colonies met in general Congress at Philadelphia. p 75–100. Journal of Christopher Gist companion of Major George Washington in 1754— Journal of a Treaty held in 1793. with Indians Northwest of the Ohio. p. 109–176.

Heavy showers of rain in the morning, and cloudy remainder of the day. I received a Letter from my wife enclosing one from William S. Smith to Thomas B. Johnson— His condition is so critical, that his Sisters feared if the Letter should be communicated to him it might snap the attenuated thread of his life— Yet they did not dare to break the seal to ascertain its contents, and my wife enclosed it to me with a request that I would return it to Mr Smith, and intimate to him that if he has any application to make to Mr Johnson, it would be advisable that he should make it through me— I enclosed accordingly Mr Smith’s Letter back to himself and answered the one from my wife.— Mr Curtis came just before our dinnertime; and having dined before he left home abridged his visit. I agreed to meet him between 10 and 11 to morrow morning at my Son’s office in Boston— We have a final answer to give to Petty Vaughan of London who exacts a bond of indemnity from us for his own unauthorised transactions as a condition to his payment of a large sum in his hands, due to us as Executors of Ward N. Boylston’s Will.— There is also an account to be rendered to the judge of probate at Boston, for the settlement of the claim ofFuller, administrator of Moses Gill on the Administration de bonis non, with the will annexed of Thomas Boylston; and a proposal from the purchasers of the Tremont theatre to be considered— My Son went to Boston and returned to dine— After dinner, I rode with Mrs Charles and Arthur round the Braintree Meeting house square, leaving Miss Welsh at Mr John Greenleaf’s and taking her up as we returned. In the ride, I observed that the red Cedar trees have shared the fate of the button wood or Sycamores— They are all dying, and no one knows why— Multitudes of my Peach trees, are in the same condition. But what annoys me still more is the habit I am forming of wasting time on morning Newspapers—Garden, Nursery and Seminary forenoon visits; and siesta’s followed by an after dinner ride, and do nothing evenings This mode of life palsies the whole day—leaving me scarcely the two hours for the journal record, and one more for reading of Machiavel, and Ignatius Loyola—or to notice the Collections of the Massachusetts Historical Society— Third Series. Vol. 6— Captain John Underhill’s History of the Pequot War. p 1–28. P. Vincents History of the Pequot War. p. 29 44 Sir Ferdinando Gorges’s description of New-England p. 45–94. Captain John Smith’s Description of New-England p. 95–140. Revd. Samuel Niles’s History of the Indian and French Wars p. 154–279. (unfinished) See the notice of this work, in the Letter from my father to judge William Tudor of 23 September 1818

div.dateline: Quincy— Saturday 10 June 1843. Boston. Medford. Quincy.
div.p: Showery Night. Thick fog this morning, and Summer heat. After some hesitation I concluded to go— Rode to Boston with my Son, and Harriet Welsh, who is copying my Discourse on the New England confederacy of 1643. At my Son’s Office I found Mr Nathaniel Curtis and two of the members of the Church, purchasers of the Tremont theatre— The land on which the theatre stands was sold to its proprietors by Ward Nicholas Boylston, and it was part of the land on which the Boylston house was built fronting on school Street. The theatre fronts on Tremont Street and the portion of the lot sold by Mr Boylston was the back garden of the Boylston house. The present purchasers of the Theatre want a small additional grant for completing a passage way through from Tremont Street which they propose to purchase or to exchange for a four foot passage way opening upon School Street, no longer of use to them— We all went upon the ground and examined the premises— Several questions arose about the precise title and bounds of Mr Boylston. and of his conveyance to the proprietors of the theatre, which I thought required an examination of all the title deeds— Mr. Curtis undertook to look them up, and to answer the Committee men from the Church.— I found on looking over my file of papers relating to the demand by Petty Vaughan for a bond of indemnity, that the bond proposed by him was not among them, so that a further search for it must be made: and I am also to state an account for the judge of probate, to close the administration of Thomas Boylston Estate— This business being thus disposed of for the present, I concluded to leave the carriage at Boston and go to Medford by the Lowell railway cars— The Sun was out with scorching summer heat, and in walking to the depot, immediately after another half hour’s walk, I flushed my face almost into a fever— In 15 minutes we were at Medford, and dined at Mr Peter C. Brooks’s with the members of the agricultural Society— While we were at dinner there was a gathering of thunder showers, which hastened us to the depot to which we were taken by Mr Brooks’s carriage at 6 O’Clock— There we waited till ten minutes before 7. when the Cars from Lowell half an hour belated took us up, and in fifteen minutes landed us at the depot in Boston. Benjamin the Coachman was there waiting for us with the Carriage and took us home to Quincy; through threatened thunder showers all the way, but only one slight sprinkling of rain— There was a drenching shower half an hour after we got home— Charles was quite unwell the whole day.

The night was so warm, and finding the thermometer in my study at 70 with a thick fog, and a South wind, I invested myself in summer garments, and threw open my windows. But before I was called to breakfast the wind wheeled round to the Northeast the fog resolved itself into a heavy rain, and I resumed my broad cloth velvet and flannel cloathing— The rain continued so that I went morning and afternoon to Meeting in the Carriage, but in the afternoon I walked home Mr Lunt preached, in the forenoon, from 1. Peter 5.7. “Casting all your care upon him; for he careth for you.” The Doctrine of a special Providence seems to be congenial to that of guardian Angels; of Cherubim and Seraphim, and an innumerable company of Angels and Archangels— Ministering Spirits, intimated somewhat obscurely in all parts of the Scriptures, and blended with that of evil Spirits, the theory of which is organized by the poetical imagination of John Milton, so that my old Law master Theophilus Parsons used to say that he considered the Paradise lost, as a narrative of facts of equal authenticity with the Bible— But then if the universal cause, acts not by partial but by general Laws, in what sense can God be said to care for individuals? The argument of Mr Lunts sermon was to urge from considerations of fitness the probable conjecture of a protecting Providence, which is scarcely reconcileable with the existence of evil— To this belief of a special protecting Providence, that of retribution in a future world is indispensable— Mr Lunt’s afternoon text was from Matthew 13.31. “Another parable put he forth unto them saying, The kingdom of Heaven is like to a grain of mustard-seed, which a man took and sowed in his field: 32 which indeed is the least of all seeds: but when it is grown, it is the greatest among herbs, and becometh a tree, so that the birds of the air come and lodge in the branches thereof.” In this chapter it seems as if Jesus felt it necessary to guard against the imputation of revolutionary designs in his ministry— He speaks of the kingdom of Heaven, in eight several parables in complex imagery, which even his hearers did not understand— He likens his doctrines to seeds and plants, with various results, and in one instance explains his meaning— His object in this parable is to admonish his disciples that they must not judge of the results of his husbandry from the smallness of the seed sown by him. It was perhaps necessary to convey these ideas in figurative language, to disarm the jealously both of the Jewish and of the Roman Institutions which were to be subverted and demolished by the kingdom of Heaven— But I can pursue these subjects no further. I finished reading the article in the Edinburgh Review upon Ignatius Loyola and his Associates, a bloated caricature portraiture of the men, but giving no idea of the Institution.

So says the American Almanac of this year. The Massachusetts Register of the present year marks the Sun rise of this day at 4.28. and the first of the solstice to morrow or the day after— The Solstice of the American Almanac, begins on the 11th. and ends on the 19th.—9 days at 4.22.— The Solstice of the Massachusetts Register begins on the 14th. and ends on the 28th. 15 days at 4.27.— Both Calendars differ from themselves in other years— I saw the Sun rise from the S.E. corner of Charles’s house and found he had reached the extreme of his Northern declination as I had observed in June 1839. since which I have passed every month of June till this year at Washington— Passed Midshipman J. Q. Adams was here this morning to take leave—ordered to join the Sloop of War Decatur now at Norfolk, Virginia, under orders for the Coast of Africa, part of the Treaty Squadron of eighty guns— He is appointed sailing master of the Decatur— He was here again in the evening with his mother; and his Sister Elizabeth, and is to depart to-morrow— Charles Faxon a Tax collector of the town of Braintree, brought me a highway tax-bill of 1 dollar 96 cents which I paid, and Samuel White for my subscription of 10 dollars for the sufferers by the late fire of the Faxon and other houses— Mr Lanman a son of the late U.S. Senator from Connecticut Samuel Lanman, with Dr and Mrs Coit, Mrs and Miss Hubbard and a small child, all from Connecticut were here this afternoon about 5. minutes; for the single purpose of seeing and speaking to me— I fear they thought my reception of them cold— I rode with Mrs Charles over Milton hill— I answered a Letter from William Pitt Fessenden, a member of the last Congress from Portland Maine, who has been charged in an abolitionist address to the people of that State, with lukewarmness in the support of the right of petition. He wrote to me requesting my testimony, as to his course in the house on this subject. I have given him my testimony— The abolitionist charges against him are unjust—but zeal in support of the right of petition can do nothing in the Congress of the United States— I wrote this answer with great difficulty, much hesitation, and not a little imprudence in lifting up one corner of the curtain which covers the hideous reality of the Slave ascendancy in the Government of this Union— The double representation of the Slave owners in the House of Representatives and in the electoral colleges for the choice of President and Vice-President.— Semper ego auditor tantum?

My Son went to Boston, and returned to dinner; suffering with a severe cold and cough. The spell of idleness is yet upon me, and I have no hope of emerging from it— To answer Mr Fessenden’s Letter, I wanted the Journal of the U.S. House of Representatives for the second Session of the 27th. Congress; which was in the chest, which was sent round by water from Washington, and has at last arrived— I opened the chest to find the book, and with it found an enormous budget of Documents and pamphlets to be filed, assorted and bound—which took me not less than three hours to put into complete disorder— I went to the Bank and made a deposite there, but could not reach it before the Noon day bell had rung, when the morning business of the Bank is closed and the doors are shut— But the Cashier Bartlett’s Son came and received my deposit and balanced my book. The grass in my front yard and seminary was mowed— Elizabeth C. Adams dined with us, and after dinner I rode with her, and Mrs Charles and Arthur over Milton hill and bridge to Dorchester, returning by the upper bridge over the Neponset stream— Nicholas Machiavel, and Ignatius Loyola have fallen into a Mesmeric sleep, but I received this morning a Letter from Asa Walker and two others a Committee of Correspondence for a public meeting of the citizens of Bangor and vicinity, holden on the 27th. of last month, and at which a Resolution was adopted to observe the first of next August as the Anniversary of West India emancipation, by a public address and other suitable exercises—and the committee appointed to carry the resolution into execution, invite me to deliver the address— The temptation is almost irresistible, but must be resisted— My time is not yet come— How shall I answer this Letter? The same question is of more than daily recurrence. I have for example an invitation dated the 19th. of April from a Committee of the Directors of the Bunker hill monument association, to unite with them in celebrating the completion of that monument, by a civic and military procession, and an Address, by the Hon Daniel Webster— Upon this pageant has been engrafted another to bedaub with glory John Tyler the Slave-breeder, who is coming with all his Court in gaudy trappings of mock-royalty to receive the homage of hungry Sycophants under colour of doing homage to the principles of Bunker hill martyrdom. I answered this invitation, declining to attend, with a struggle between inclination and decorum, to suppress the most imperative motive for my absence, the disdain to be associated with the mouth worship of Liberty from the lips of the Slave-breeder. I succeeded but indifferently in veiling my emotions, and touched upon the martyrdom of Bunker hill only by transparent generalities, which will yet provoke censure.

Alonzo Taft came this morning and enquired what had been done with a claim for reimbursement of money paid by him for his passage home from Gibraltar in 1825. when he had been discharged by Commodore Rogers from the Squadron commanded by him without provision for his passage to this Country— He reminded me that nearly two years since he had applied to me concerning this claim— That I had advised him to make a written statement of it fortified with his own affidavit, and such other testimony to the facts as he could procure, and send these papers to me, and I would attend to the claim at Washington. He said he had accordingly made the statement in writing and sworn to it— Had obtained the deposition of another man, and sent all the papers to me here at Quincy, since which he had not heard from me concerning his claim.— The whole subject had totally vanished from my Memory—and after a search of at least four hours I found only the entry in my diary of 7. October 1841. confirming the fact that he did apply to me on that day, and that I gave him the advice precisely as now represented by him— But neither in my diary, nor in my voluminous files of papers can I find a trace of the papers which he says he sent to me, or that I ever received them— I believe I never did— This incident admonishes me that my minutes for remembrance of all the claims to which my attention is due have been sadly deficient in system— Is it too late to improve it?— I received an invitation from Joseph T. Buckingham and 8 others Committee of Arrangements for the Directors of the Bunker hill monument association, to dine at Faneuil Hall on the 17th. and a Card of invitation from the city Council—to a dinner at the Tremont House to be given to the President of the United States on the 15th Friday both of which invitations I declined— I rode to Mount Wollaston this afternoon with Mrs Charles and her three younger sons Charles, Henry and Arthur— From the beach below the mount there is a full view of the Bunker hill column from top to bottom— The Revd. Charles Spear, an itinerant Universalist Minister came and sold me for a dollar, as a gift of friendship a duodecimo volume, of his composition on the names and titles of the Lord Jesus Christ—the fourteenth edition— He spoke of his poverty—of his self education of his pulmonary complaints which interdicted him from preaching; and intending a voyage to England where one edition of his work has been printed, he inquired with some solicitude whether it was held in Europe discreditable to an author to sell his own works— He said he was now preparing a great work on capital punishment— Miss Sampson is here working at her profession. I received a Letter of the 10th. from my wife—
15. III.20. Thursday— Sun rose 4:22.— Set 7:38. Or 4:27— 7.33

The first is by the rule of the American Almanac—counting from the first beam of the rising to the last of the setting Sun— The Massachusetts Register computes only the time when the whole disk is above the horizon; and there is a difference of 1 minute and 40 seconds between each of the two computations, allowing 3 minutes and 20 seconds for the rising, and the same for the setting of the disk— I was going to the gate for the afternoon ride in the carriage with Mrs Charles when Coll William H. Freeman came and detained me at home. He informed me that he is to be tried by a Court martial in about 3 weeks at Middletown in the State of Connecticut; upon a charge of scandalous conduct unbecoming an Officer and a gentleman; and the specification is for treating contemptuously his superior by a paragraph, in a Letter to the Secretary of the Navy— He read to me the Letter containing the obnoxious passage, and the Letter from the Secretary of the Navy informing him that he had determined to bring him to trial: and the Coll. asked me if I would assist him as his Counsel— I answered that I earnestly desired to do any thing in my power to befriend him— But that I had never practiced as an advocate before Courts Martial— Had long since ceased to practice in the Courts of civil jurisdiction, and apprehended I was not competent to do justice to his cause as his advocate— Besides which there might be doubts of the propriety of my appearing in that capacity— He did not press his request, but said he should want my testimony— I said I would cheerfully give that if it should be necessary for him, either by a deposition before the judge of the United States judge of the District Court at Boston or by attending in person before the Court martial at Middletown— He intimated his intention to apply to Mr Choate the Senator from this State in Congress to be his Counsel; and I thought he could not do better. Mr Armstrong came to invite me to go to his house on Saturday after the return procession from Bunker’s hill, and before that from the State house to the dinner at Faneuil Hall— I thanked him for his kindness, but I told him I did not propose to be present at any part of the celebrations of that day. The political device of turning the Bunker-hill monument address into a sycophantic tribute of homage to John Tyler is Webster’s, and Boston is of all the Cities in the world the spot to play it off to the greatest advantage— I saw the sun rise and set from Charles’s house. It rose clear and the day was fine the Sun had just reached the border of the western horizon, clear when a dark cloud came over the disk as it was descending and eclipsed his upper limb.

The Sun rose not quite clear but sufficiently so to mark the point of the horizon at which the first beam emerges, or rather at which the revolving orb of Earth brings him above the surface— I took an hour of exercise with my knife and handsaw, and examining my seminary seedling trees— The hay from the enclosure, mowed last Tuesday, was got into the barn just in time to save it from the heavy rain for which the clouds had been gathering all the morning and which continued till about 3 in the afternoon, when it held up, without clearing off: Charles went to Boston with his daughter Louisa Catherine, and returned to dine— This was the of the reception of the President of the United States by the city of Boston. He comes with his cabinet and a ridiculous parade of ostentation to attend the celebration of the completion of the Bunker hill monument; a costly pageant first got up by Joseph Tinker Buckingham President of the Bunker-hill Monument association and Editor of the Boston Courier, the most respectable of Websters Trumpeters— The corner stone of the monument was laid by La Fayette on the 17th of June 1825—on which occasion delivered an elegant Discourse— He is to deliver another— The object now is to glorify him— A formal invitation was sent to him last fall immediately after the completion of the monument inviting him to the performance of this service, which he then accepted; and the invitation and acceptance were published in newspapers all over the country— The invitation to the President and his Cabinet to attend is a political device of Webster’s own—a gull-trap for popularity—both for himself and for Tyler, by which he hopes to whistle back his whig friends whom he had cast off as a huntsman his pack, and who now threaten to hunt him like the hounds of Acteon— The reception of the President this day had all the appearances of cordiality, not withstanding a drenching rain to cool it— He is lodged at the Tremont house at an enormous expense to the city; was entertained there with a sumptuous dinner, by the City Council, and went to the theatre and to an evening party at the Postmaster Gordon’s house— I was invited to the dinner, but sent an excuse— Spent the day quietly at my house, writing to my wife and filing and assorting letters and papers, and making little progress even in disorder— Collections of the Massachusetts Historical Society Third Series. Vol 7—published in 1838. Account of the Massachusetts historical Society, by Revd William Jenks D.D. p. 5–26. Post-Office Department 48–90. Model of Christian Charity by Governor Winthrop. p. 31–47.— D’Aulney and La Tour p. 90–121. Instructions to Randolph p. 129–138 Commission to Sir Edmund Andros p. 139–149 Papers relating to his Administration 150–195. Higginson Letters. 196–221. Colonel Quarrys memorial p. 222–242. List of Portraits in the Hall of the Historical Society p. 285–291. I am projecting remarks upon the majority and minority reports on the treatment of coloured Seamen in the Southern ports—

This was the day of the great celebration of the completion of the monument on Bunker hill; and never since the existence of the three hills was there such a concourse of strangers upon their sides as has been assembled on the banks of “Majestic Charles” this day— What a name in the annals of mankind is Bunker hill?— What a day, was the 17th. of June 1775? and what a burlesque upon them both is an oration upon them by Daniel Webster, and a pilgrimage of John Tyler and his Cabinet of Slave-drivers, to desecrate the solemnity by their presence! And then a dinner at Faneuil Hall in honour of a President of the United States hated and despised by those who invited him to it, themselves as cordially hated and despised by him. I have throughout my life had an utter aversion to all pageants, and public dinners, and never attended one, when I could decently avoid it— I was a student at Cambridge when on the 17th. of June 1786. Charles river bridge was opened— The colleges were emptied on that day of the Students who flocked to witness the procession and the pageant— I passed the day in the solitude of my Study, and dined almost alone in the Hall. I had then no special motive for my absence— But now with the ideal association of the thundering cannon which I heard and the smoke of burning Charlestown which I saw on that awful day, combined with this Pyramid of Quincy granite, and Daniel Webster spouting with a negro holding an umbrella over his head, and John Tyler’s nose with a shadow outstreching that of the monumental column; how could I have witnessed all this at once without an unbecoming burst of indignation or of laughter? Daniel Webster is a heartless traitor to the cause of human freedom. John Tyler is a Slave-monger—what have these to do with the Quincy granite pyramid on the brow of Bunker’s hill?— What have these to do, with a dinner in Faneuil hall, but to swill like swine and grunt about the rights of man?— I stayed at home and visited my seedling trees; and heard the cannonades of the rising, the meridian and the setting Sun—and answered a Letter from the Revd. Joseph Emerson dated at New-London Connecticut making enquiries about a translation of Voltaire’s philosophical dictionary, published under the name of John Quincy Adams, and secretly circulating as he says, about the country, as my work— I saw the Sun set from the front of Charles’s house, at the extremity of his northwestern declination, and as I heard the cannonade salute of the closing day, and saw the smoke ascending from the side of the pyramid, the top of which was full in view; then came in forcible impulse to my memory the cannonade, and the smoke and the fire of the 17th. of June 1775— I waited to see the revolving fire of the Boston Light house kindled, and then returned to my peaceful home

The Revd. Benjamin Kent now keeper of a school for girls at Roxbury preached for Mr Lunt this morning with a double text. Romans 7:24. “O wretched man that I am! who shall deliver me from the body of this death?” and Philippians 4.13. “I can do all things through Christ which strengtheneth me.” The doctrine of the discourse was that the will of a perfect Christian fortified by conscience is omnipotent. That nothing is impossible for it to atchieve; and to elucidate the principle, he presented a parallel between these two passages from the writings of St Paul first in the epistle to the Romans in the agonies of despair and then four years later to the Philippians in the exultation of a glorious victory and triumph by the strength of Christ assisting him— The first written in the midst of the terrible struggle of his conversion, and while he was yet uncertain of its success. The last was written after his conversion was consummated, and his confidence in himself with the strength imparted to him by Christ his lord and master was unbounded. Upon this theme Mr Kent amplified and dilated until he reminded me of the story which I once heard Dr Franklin tell of a convent of monks who had a very inconvenient hill in front of their monastery, and upon their faith like a grain of mustard seeds being sufficient cast the mountain into the sea, set up a general onset of prayer to remove the mountain, which they perseveringly pursued till tired of the obstinate adherence of the mountain to its place one of the friars gave out that there was a mistake in the translation of the text, and that the true reading should be that with faith like a mountain it is possible to move a mustard seed— Mr Kent and Mr Lunt dined with us— They were both at the Bunker-hill celebration yesterday; which went off admirably well. Webster’s Oration was brilliant and eminently successful. Two hours and seven minutes— Suitable to the occasion, and often rapturously cheered— The dinner at Faneuil hall was also very well ordered and passed off agreeably.— The cheering of Webster was hearty and general—that of the President feeble and cold— Mr Kents text this afternoon was from Proverbs 16.32. “He that ruleth his spirit is better than he that taketh a city.” The Sermon was supplementary to that of the morning, upon the extreme importance and excellence of the faculty of self-controul Mr Lunt gave notice that the Revd. John Gregory would deliver at 5 O’Clock this afternoon a Temperance Lecture and Mr B. O. Tyler would exhibit his design for a family temperance pledge— Some incident already forgotten turned my attention lately to an enquiry into the scriptural notices of Angels, and I looked into Basnage’s history of the Jews—Book 4. chapters 9 and 10. where I found more than I looked for, and more than was very agreeable.

Visitors must account for the idleness of this day— I rose with a dull head ache; and the exercise of the morning consisted in sawing and whittling sticks for stakes. Two brothers named Adams, William van Bergen and Herman C. inhabitants of Coxakie and of Athens in the County of Green, and State of New-York on Hudson river, came and introduced themselves to me— They came from home to attend the Bunker hill celebration, and took the occasion to visit me, and to make some enquiries concerning their own lineage— Their grandfather Joshua Adams removed about eighty years ago, from Turkey Hill, in Hingham, to Egremont, whence their father some years after emigrated to the place where they now reside— There he settled as a practising physician, raised a family of children and died— They wished to know whether Joshua was a descendant from the Patriarch Henry, but I rather thought he was not— The passed an hour with me in conversation chiefly about the family, and after, they went away— Herman C. returned, and said he had a son, to whom he had given my name, about 7 years old, and he requested me to write a few lines of advice that he might keep as an autograph; and I promised that I would— Mr Stow is recorder of the City of Buffalo, in the State of New York He brought me recommendatory Letters from Millard Fillmore and from Genl. Peter B. Porter—the latter very kindly urging me to pay them a visit in that neighbourhood: to which Mr Stow added his own very friendly solicitations— I do not deceive myself by mistaking this earnest desire to hear me for any thing more than mere curiosity—but it is friendly, and claims my gratitude— I believe there is not a man in the world more unfit for self-exhibition at public meetings and banquet dinners— When I go to them it is with feelings of a culprit to punishment than of a victor to triumph— I told Mr Stow that I could not indulge the hope of ever meeting in public the people of buffalo, but should be ever grateful for their kindness and would pray for their prosperity. Mr William Cost Johnson paid me also a visit, with a Mr Chapman—a stranger. Mr Johnson came to witness the Bunker hill monument celebration, and leaves Boston to morrow Morning, returning to Washington— Miss Anna Henshaw with her brother Samuel came this afternoon, on a visit to Mrs Charles, and Mr Tyler to shew me the portrait of my great-grandfather John Quincy at two years of age, painted in 1691 and now refreshed with a coat of his varnish— I rode in the Carriage with Mrs Charles to Mount Woolaston, stopping at Mrs T. B. Adams’s to leave a Letter to her from her son Isaac Hull.

Computation of the American Almanac exhibiting one minute of southern declination for the rising Sun, and one minute of continuing Northern declination for the setting sun— The length of the day remains 15 hours 17 minutes: the longest of the year. Another day absorbed by visitors— Charles went to Boston with his daughter, and returned to dine.— He brought the account of the decease this morning between 5 and 6. O’Clock of Hugh S. Legaré of South Carolina, Attorney General of the United States, and acting Secretary of State— He died at the house of his friend Mr George Ticknor, to which he had been removed the day before from his lodgings at the Tremont house— He had been invited as a member of the Presidents cabinet to the monumental celebration— The duties of his two departments prevented him from accompanying the President on his journey; but he left Washington so as to reach the Tremont house on Friday and was present at the dinner given to the President by the City Council at that house on that day— He was then much indisposed and the next day so ill, that he was unable to attend the celebration at the hill. His disease which was bilious colic continued increasing in violence, and inaccessible to all medical treatment till he expired. He was an able, and a very amiable man—by far the best of the Presidents present associates— Just as I was called to dinner, came in Doctor Goodale, a stranger from the Western part of the State of New York— He introduced himself, and asked numerous questions of whig politics, and particularly concerning the prospects of John Tyler at the next Presidential Election— There is no doubt he believes this idle pageant and personal courtesy will draw upon him over powering popularity— The experiment has in part succeeded, and its total failure is certainly not yet demonstrated. He visited Lowell yesterday, with a numerous train and was received with tolerable cordiality— Mr Alexander Marsh came to make enquiries about the family of that name— His father named Esek Marsh went from this town some seventy years ago, and took with him this person then a boy who seems to have had no communication with this town or with his relatives left here— I referred him to the two brothers residing between this and the Stone temple; but he appeared not satisfied with that, and inquired if I knew any thing of a family here by the name of Hamilton— Mr Edward A Newton of Pittsfield, and Mrs Newton paid us an afternoon visit. She is a daughter of my old friend the late Dudley Atkins Tyng, but I had never seen her before— There very urgent in the invitation of me to the agricultural anniversary at Pittsfield next October— Ride after they were gone with Mrs Charles and the baby to Milton.
Sun rose 4.23. Set 7:40.— Day 15 h. 17 m

I saw the Sun rise and set—still at the solstice; clear the whole day, and the first unequivocal summer day we have had this Season. As I have given up almost entirely the exercise of walking, and believing as I do that strenuous exercise of the body is yet a necessary of life to me, I am devoting two hours of the morning, immediately after sunrise to labour for my seedling trees. I am ashamed that after fifteen years search for the secret of raising trees from the seed, I am as ignorant of it as before I began— I now despair of producing any useful result from my labours in this respect. But I have many trees at different stages of their growth, which I may cherish into useful trees. My most successful experiments have been in manuring the ground where the seeds are planted; and I am about to resume that occupation with another, sawing and cutting twigs for stakes. This is hard work and squeezes perspiration out of the skin, as from the peel of an Orange— It is wasted time but necessary exercise— Elizabeth C. Adams was here after breakfast, and then Deacon Spear, who proposed to me to visit my woodlots, adjoining to which Daniel Baxter has purchased a lot which did belong to the late Ebenezer Adams— I referred Deacon Spear to my Son to fix a day when we should all go and make this survey, and discuss vicinage with Mr Baxter— After dinner I was visited by the Revd Benjamin Kent, and his brother in Law, Mr Bradford who has resided some years in China, whence he returned about two years since— Mr Kent had mentioned to me, sundry relics from the combustion of Miles Standish’s house in Duxbury—an old rusty hinge and door latch—a piece of the floor burnt to charcoal a small fragment from what he thought a pane of painted glass— All which he dug out from the ruins of the house, for which he dug more than a century after it was burnt and found fifteen feet under the surface. He had also a small viol full of char’d wheat seeds of which he found a bushel at the same search— He gave me these relics, and left with me to examine it, a large volume with antient manuscript deeds and Letters, and three or four volumes of manuscript Sermons among which one volume containing several Sermons as early as 1680 by my great grandmother Quincy’s father John Norton Minister at Hingham— Mr Legare’s funeral took place at 10 this morning at Trinity Church; under which his body is deposited—and at 4 O’Clock this afternoon Mr John Tyler self Styled President of the United States with his Cabinet took the Cars of the Norwich Rail-road on their return to Washington—

A cloudless day of oppressive Summer heat. Two hours of the morning wasted in idle labour to keep alive the scanty remnant of my seedling trees— Nine tenths of the seeds that I have sown, have failed to come up, or perished— Of the remaining tenth—two thirds have been taken up and transplanted to my Sons grounds, or to those of Mr Robinson the Episcopal Minister— My record which I have kept from year to year of almost all my plantations, has fallen into inextricable confusion, from its very minuteness— Four fifths of the cherished seeds which came up and flourished for a time have withered and been extirpated so long that I have lost even the memory; while the Nursery gardens and Seminary, are now overstocked with seedlings which choak one another. I have trees now. Oaks, Apples, Shagbarks, pignuts, Ash, Maple and Cherry which will outlive centuries, unless cut down, uprooted or blasted by lightnings I take pleasure in watching their growth, and in the thought of leaving them to grow till my grand children shall remember me in finding shelter and shade under them. But I have never been able to impart my marotte to any one of them. If I could I have no doubt that my successor would have improved the art of planting and the Science of dendrology— Among the rest he would have discovered the folly of wasting time upon the cultivation of trees not suited to the climate—Apricots, Nectarines, Cork, Willow and live Oaks: and he would have found the art of cultivating pears, plums, and cherries in perfection which I have sought in vain— My Philadelphia Seminary maple, seed sown 1. June 1835 measures now 19 inches round the trunk, and is about 25 feet high— Shoots are putting out from the stems of seedling English Oaks of the third year, crop’d by the Scythe of the Mower in the Seminary, on the 13th. Mr Francis Tookey is a student at the Law School in Cambridge having been there one year and nine months, and has three months more to finish his term— He says he visited me, once before in 1838. of which I had no recollection— He asked me for an autograph, and I gave him my sign manual, on a small card engraving of Durand’s portrait— Mr Enoch Hunt was here towards evening when I was reading on the Settee in front of the house— He said he thought I should not be able to bear the fatigues of the next Session of Congress. Collections of the Massachusetts historical Society. Third Series Vol 8. 1843. Extract from the Chronicle of Bernaldez p. 5–69. Bartholomew Gosnold’s Letter to his father 1602. p. 70. Archer’s Account of Gosnold’s Voyage p. 72–82 Brereton’s Account of Gosnold’s Voyage p. 83–93 Tracts appended to Brereton p. 94–124. Rosiers account of Waymouth’s 1605 p. 125 Levett’s Voyage 1623 p 125. Savage Gleanings for New-England history— p. 243.

The declination of the Sun Southward is already perceptible since Tuesday last both morning and evening, though not marked in the American Almanac. I took off a limb from the black willow South of the bridge over the brook in the lane between my house and Charles’s and slip’d from it several twigs which I stuck down as stakes, to ascertain whether any of them will take root. This experiment I have heretofore made with full success both with willows, and button woods.— But the button woods and red Cedars are now perishing all over the Country no one knows why or from what cause— I had a new hinge put on to a tool shed in the garden, which was there in my fathers time, and kept the tools— The lower hinge of the shed door was broken I believe when I came into possession—the door could not be closed and a spade and two hoes have disappeared— It is close to a spot which I have found favourable for raising delicate seedlings the first and second years till they are fit for transplantation. I began the manuring of my plats. My Seminary teems with apple seedlings from two six feet high, pushing up their plumelets with unusual rapidity, but meeting with two enemies: the aphis, and a green maggot worm which arrest their growth. There are three black walnuts in the seminary, one in the garden, and one in the Nursery, growing all with the same rank luxuriance but for which I dread the trial of the winter— The two Pennsylvania shagbarks in the Garden have to undergo the same ordeal— The budded cherry leaves are covered with rusty spots, and every cherry has an ugly speck upon it. The wild cherry’s swarm this year— Mr Curtis came this morning, with a plan of the house in School Street, of the Estate of Ward N. Boylston, and the adjoining Tremont Theatre lot with the boundary title deeds— He inclined to cede to the purchasers of the Tremont Theatre a strip ten feet wide, across the Eastern end of the lot, as an equivalent for their surrender of a five feet passage way and the use of a pump and well.— I approved and promised my assent to this arrangement— Charles went to Boston with his daughter and returned to dine— He brought me the manuscript copy of my Discourse on the New England confederacy which Harriet Welsh had undertaken but some one else has completed— Fahrenheit till noon this day was at 84 in my chamber— Then came a cooling eastern breeze and in two hours the thermometer was down to 72. The evening was rather more than cool. Mrs Henshaw and her son Samuel came out and took tea here. After which I rode with Mrs Charles to the Saltwork beach behind President Quincy’s deserted house. Elizabeth C. Adams was here this Evening. I revised in part the copy of my discourse.
Sun rose 4.23. Set 7:40. Last of the Solstice

After an abridged excursion to see the rising Sun, and to visit and study my seedling plants and listen to the matinal minstrelsy of the bobalink, the spring-bird and the robin, with the chirping of the sparrow, and the new whistle of the quail, I think all the aerial music of this time and place, I returned to my library chamber, and revised the copy of my Discourse on the New-England confederacy of 1643, furnished me by Harriett Welsh, and which I made up and despatched by the mail to James Savage, President of the Massachusetts Historical Society, at Boston— In revising this Discourse I had the opportunity of examining it with cooler judgment than I had while composing it.— I was then somewhat disqualified by the hurry, agitation, and severe disposition under which I was labouring: with a keen apprehension, that my Catarrh would disable me from delivering it, and extreme anxiety that it would if delivered be tedious and dull to the auditory— It was on the contrary happily delivered, and with as much favour from the auditory as I could have expected or ought to have desired— It is now a historical document, and a political disquisition; to be published by the Massachusetts Historical Society, and will pass to posterity as one of my contributions to the labours of that Institution.— I would it were wiser—more philosophical—more profound— I would the faculty had been conferred upon me to enlighten my brethren of the human race; to improve their condition upon earth—to rule them by the energies of the Soul— Perhaps one of the sins for which I may have to answer hereafter to answer is that of repining at the scantiness of the portion of intellect which I was endowed— The day differed from that of yesterday. A morning less intensely warm, but no east wind at noon to chill the atmosphere— I received a new packet of proposals for repairing the mill dam of the Columbian Mills, with a Letter from Mr Frye, which I immediately answered— I received also, nearly a fortnight since an invitation from Bangor an invitation to deliver an anniversary address there on the 1st. of August the day in 1838 of the total emancipation of the Slaves, in the British colonies of the West Indies— After much hesitation and deliberation I began this day an answer to this invitation: and I was occupied almost the whole afternoon in a fruitless search for the bond of indemnity to Petty Vaughan, which he requires that the Executors of Ward N. Boylston to execute before he will remit the monies held by him and belonging to the Estate. Mrs Charles rode without me to Weymouth— After Sunset there was a threat of a thunder gust and shower, which evaporated in wind, and a mere sprinkling of rain. The Atlas of this day says that Websters regret at my absence on the 17th. was not spoken.

Mr Lunt and his wife are gone upon an excursion into the State of New-York. The Revd. Dr Kendall of Plymouth preached here for him—in the morning from John 1.18. [“]No Man hath seen God at any time; the only begotten Son, which is in the bosom of the father, he hath declared him.” It was one of the sacred doctrines of the Jews that no man ever saw God or could see him and live— His voice was often heard, and his angels were often seen— He was made perceptible by fire, as to Moses in the burning bush; and to Elijah when carried up in a chariot of fire— Moses had the hardihood to ask to see him, and he passed before him so as to shew his hinder parts—but it was only a storm of wind— By the incarnation God was made manifest in the flesh; and here the Messiah, said to be in the bosom of the father, it is further said had declared him— Dr Kendall’s argument was that the gospel of Christ was the manifestation of God. I invited Dr Kendall to dine with us; but he asked to be excused He said he was turned of seventy and never dined between the services and that what he most needed was repose— But that he would cheerfully walk home with me after the second service—in which of course I acquiesced. After dinner, the text was from Hebrews 11.5. “By faith Enoch was translated that he should not see death: and was not found, because God had translated him: for before his translation he had this testimony, that he pleased God.” The story and character of Enoch are among the most mysterious parts of the Bible— Scarcely any thing is said of him in the old Testament, except that which is noted in this passage of the Epistle to the Hebrews— That he walked with God, and was not because God took him; Why he was so privileged we are not told—nor how he was thus removed from Earth, exempted from the common law of human nature to die. St. Paul says it was by Faith; and because he pleased God. I scarcely can tell by what process it was, that Dr Kendall made this text the theme for giving a brief historical statement of the ministers of the gospel who were settled in the old Plymouth Colony before the commencement of the present century—of whom only two or three still survive. He is himself the only one still in office as Pastor of a Church, and he has now a colleague settled with him— He paid a tribute of friendship and of honour to the memory of the late Senior pastor of the Quincy church, who died very suddenly on theoflast, and he spoke reverently of Dr Henry Ware whose Ordination as Minister of the first Church at Hingham I attended in September 1787. and who is yet living, emeritus professor of divinity at Harvard University. Dr Kendall came home with me after the second Service—and after walking up the hill to see the Sunset from the front of Charles’s house, parted from us in peace.

I continue my morning exercise, and observe the mysteries of vegetation upon my seedling trees— Among them is the difference between the plants whose growth is continuous through the summer—those which have but one term of growth of a few weeks in the Spring; and those which have two— This difference is remarkable in the Oaks— The black having but one; and the red two six weeks growths in a summer— On the 13th. instt Dennis mowed the grass in the seminary, and cropped the stem of a third year seedling of an English white Oak in Mary-Louisa’s patch—a lateral shoot has put out from the mutilated stem and is now in the process of opening leaves— The same thing is happening to a second year seedling in the garden, which I accidentally cropped about the same time.— But the English white Oak seedlings of this Season have ceased to grow and the most thrifty of them is not more than 4 inches high. The Philadelphia maple continues to grow the whole summer One in the Seminary and one in the Garden from the seeds sown by me 1. June 1835 are 17 inches in circumference and 20 feet high— About noon I met Mr E. Price Greenleaf in the Garden and he inspected with me all my trees— He cautioned me against trimming the trees after the 22d. of June; and he brought to my notice the depredations upon all my trees of insects and worms almost numberless— The thriftiest of my apple trees, in its tenth year and already bearing has half a dozen Gimlet holes just above the ground pierced by the borer— Another 14 years old and bearing freely has a worm in every apple. The Caterpillar and the Canker are angels commissioned for destruction. The beetle or dorbug nips the shoot in its prime, and invisible thieves in the darkness of the night strip the Oaks of their tender leaves, and yield them up to withering decay— The drought, the flood, the frost, the Sun, the gale, the blight, the field mouse at the root and the green louse or aphis at the germ, form such a host of foes, that it is as hard to raise a tree as a child— Charles and his wife went this afternoon to Hingham in search of a School for their two eldest boys— I continued without finishing my answer to the invitation from Bangor to deliver there an Oration on the first of August in celebration of the emancipation of Slaves in the British West Indies— This answer will be instead of the oration itself; but it is already too long and must be much longer to be worthy of the theme. I shall probably not send it after all, but I feel an irremissible duty to bear my testimony once more, before I go hence against Slavery. To select the time, the place and the manner is a subject of great consideration and must be neither precipitated nor too long delayed— My ideas are yet crude indigested and confused. I will begin to collect and assort them in this Letter, with the firm resolve to persevere in the pursuit. I began also this afternoon to read Dr Henry Wares Inquiry into the foundation Evidences and Truth’s of Religion—of which he sent me last year a copy, the receipt of which I have not yet acknowledged.
Sun rose 4:24. intercepted. Set 7:40 crystal clear.

My Marotte gives me abundant exercise for two hours of the morning, and my only apprehension now is of its encroaching on my hours of labour. I received this morning a Letter from my wife dated last Friday in which she informs me that her brother is better, and she proposes to leave Washington to morrow and expects to arrive here next Saturday. Charles and his wife had already concluded to go up the hill to their own house to morrow— Charles went to Boston with his daughter this morning and returned to dine. His wife took her two eldest boys this morning to Hingham, and left them at a boarding school kept by Mr and Mrs Wilder— Mrs Wilder is a daughter of Nehemiah Parsons, whose wife was the only daughter of the old and faithful friend of my childhood and youth John Thaxter— I walked this morning with my Sons third son, Henry Brooks, to his school Mrs.Their youngest boy Arthur, an uncommonly beautiful and forward child was born 23 July 1841— A Mr Mill, originally from New-Hampshire, now attached to a college or high school at Crawfordsville Indiana came in near our dinnertime, having walked this morning from Abington— Charles White, the President of the College, he says is a lineal descendent from Perigrine White, the first born of New-England— Mr Mill said their buildings had been burnt down, and he was travelling to solicit contributions for re building them— I invited him to dine with us; but he was afraid of losing the afternoon stage to Boston, and declined— He made several enquiries to know if the college could obtain a collection of the distributable public documents to supply the place of those which were consumed in the fire— He was also desirous of procuring a complete collection of the publications of the Massachusetts Historical Society— And he spoke of the Representatives from Indiana in the last Congress, and particularly of Mr Lane, who was no favourite politician to him— Elizabeth C. Adams was here this afternoon. So intense was the heat that my afternoon was lost in idleness— I resorted two or three times to my hard bed, but could neither sleep nor repose— I read two Chapters of Dr Ware’s Inquiry into the foundation, Evidences and Truths of Religion; but I could neither understand nor take interest in what I read. I was obliged to lay the book aside, and had no spirit or impulse to take up any other. I was not able to get through one page of my Letter to Bangor— As Sunset approached we all went up and saw it from the front of Charles’s house in cloudless splendor descend beneath the horizon— There was a refreshing breeze and we sat under the portico, till the town curfew bell of 9. sounded our retreat— In my concert of birds the other morning I forgot to mention the black-bird, blue-bird, and swallow, all of which join in the chorus.

My morning exercise becomes tedious unless I fix my attention upon particular plants of which I have now a considerable number in the critical state of uncertainty between life and death— The summer house Apple tree, the growth of which has been so cheeringly rapid, is doomed to death by the borer worm— The tree in front of my study window, under the brow eastward of the old horse chesnut; after suffering from the Scythe in 1834. and the field mouse three or four years later has now a stock in circumference about the size of my thumb and six feet high; and if duly guarded from its foes will form a valuable tree— Upon almost every patch into which I gradually year by year since 1834 divided the seminary I have now growing young seedlings of different kinds together with others transplanted all with the intention of finishing by raising one tree on each patch.— On many of them I have peach trees some of which have borne, and others but last summer were of the fairest promise. They are now little better than totally destroyed— I shall be compelled to uproot them all.— I have very few pears, and not one of thrifty growth—few and very unpromising cherries— Three black walnuts, transplanted in 1840 from the garden, and now for the first time seeming likely to live— One solitary shagbark walnut first hopeful this year—perhaps 20 English white oaklings whose fate is dubious— One beautiful Apple tree now six feet high and a strait stem alongside of a stunted, transplanted but yet finely growing Philadelphia maple. The multitude of these trees furnishes me occupation for two hours every morning merely to look at them— The result of all my labours for the cultivation of trees from the seed will probably be lost; but if I could inoculate my son or one of my grandson with my own fancy for seedling trees he would raise the most magnificent forest and the most delicious orchard that ever was known in New England— Charles and his family removed this day, up the hill to his house, and Louisa C. Smith, came out from Boston by Gillet’s stage, to keep house for me till the arrival of my wife from Washington— This day was intensely hot; so that although I finished the record of yesterday before Noon I could accomplish nothing further for the remainder of the day. I attempted in vain to finish my Letter to Bangor, and was equally unsuccessful in attempting to make progress in reading Dr Henry Wares Inquiry. I find it however work of profound interest, and have determined if it please the great disposer to read it in the spirit of the Inquiry itself— As a subject which it is one of the great duties of my life to examine and to penetrate to the utmost extent of the capacity which God has given me

I had sown in 1840 Apple and Pear seeds in a short row between the Eastern door and gale under an old Althaea tree which must soon be taken away.— They came up but have been cropped by the scythe every Spring with the grass, from which the mower could not discern them—when I came out here the middle of May I could not discover the trace of one of them in the grass— Yesterday I found three of them, with leaves put out since they were cut down—perhaps I may save one of them. I received a Letter from my wife of the 26th. last Monday advising me that she had postponed her journey home for a few days, her brother being again worse, and Mrs Frye threatened with a fever.— I went into Boston and attended the stated monthly meeting of the Massachusetts historical Society. Charles and his wife went in with me— The meeting of the Society was at Noon. Before going to it I paid a morning visit to Mr and Mrs Abbott Lawrence, whom I found in the bustle of packing up for a voyage to England— They are to embark in the Steamer Acadia, to sail next Saturday— The Voyage is for his health; and he says he proposes to return next October— While there he intends to sound the Peel ministers about a reciprocity Treaty; and to consult with Edward Everett but he is not reconciled to the projects or present policy of Daniel Webster, and he thinks Webster’s great device of bringing Tyler and his gang here as bobs to his Bunker hill monument kite a very small concern— I went with Charles to H. Wilson junr. a Taylor and ordered a light waistcoat and pantaloons for summer wear.— The persons above named with Charles and myself constituted the whole meeting— Several presents were received, and votes of thanks passed— My Letter to the President James Savage, with the copy of my discourse was read and placed on the files— The discourse itself he said was at the Printers, and he promised to direct that the proof sheets should be sent by the mail to me for revisal— I returned to Mr Felt the books which he had lent me— At one; the meeting adjourned and with Charles and his wife returned to our respective homes to dine— Their daughter Louisa Catherine, dined with Louisa C. Smith and me— In the afternoon there was a light shower merely of rain, but the heat before and after was totally disabling to read or write— I discovered broken ground on the seedling spot next to the kitchen— I went up the hill at Sunset which was deeply beclouded, and sat in the front of Charles’s house, with a fresh and delicious breeze till the bell at 9. called me home.

My Morning exercise encroaches too much on my hours of labour; and rising as I do at half past 3 in the morning I am called to breakfast almost before I have seated myself at the table for daily writing— This morning I discovered three more cropped apple-seedlings, in the range between the Althaea and the old horse chesnut tree— One of the crops is a mere steminches high without the trace of a bud or leaf upon it— I shall try the experiment if they can be revived, and hoed up partially the grass around them, watered the ground about their roots and gave them some refreshment of manure.— The cropd oakling in Mary Louisa’s patch has put out a new stem and fair leaves, but the tender fresh leaves of that in the garden next the kitchen, as well as those of the shagbark, have had the borders of their leaves scorched to a black cinder by one day’s heat of the Sun. Charles went to Boston and returned home to dine. The morning set in at high summer heat, and I expected a roasting day, but by 10 O’Clock there came a soft eastern breeze, which without obscuring the Sun cooled the atmosphere to a delicious temperature, and left me full power to read or write without interruption— Yet I read only a few pages of Dr Ware’s Inquiry into the foundation, evidences and truths of Religion— He begins with the foundation of religion—that is he begins by stating the temper of mind in which the inquiry should be pursued— The first section of the introduction is an argument to prove that religion is an interesting subject of inquiry.— The second that there is no reason for entering on the inquiry with a wish to find its claims without foundation in truth— These are preliminaries— Now that religion is an interesting inquiry, no one will deny who is capable of making and pursuing the inquiry at all. The desire of continued existence is planted in the nature of man— The brute creation cling to life as tenaciously as man—more tenaciously—for they never commit voluntary suicide—but they have no conception of what death is or of a state of existence after death— Man learns by experience as a witness and by tradition what death is—he sees that it is the extinction of his being— He has hopes and desires but no evidence of continued existence after death— Dr Ware’s first chapter therefore is with what evidence the inquirer ought to be satisfied on the subject.— That is—what he is to take for evidence, which is not evidence. All the Evidence is negative, and the only alternative for the inquirer is to abandon the enquiry and take his fate as it comes, or to put up with Faith as the substance of things hoped for and the evidence of things not seen.— The creation speaks for itself and discloses a creator or creators, one or more—no evidence to decide that question, but faith acknowledges only one God— I wrote two pages of my Letter to Bangor, and as Sunset approached I walked up the hill, and spent the evening under Charles’s portico, and in his Study. He told me Caleb Cushing proposed to visit me to-morrow.
